images.place: Dim Sum Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
[Soup dumplings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tangbao) are not dumplings in soup, but the reverse, steamed buns filled with soup. Of the many varieties of soup dumplings, the most common one in dim sum restaurants is [Shanghai dumplings](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiaolongbao).

**Characters**

[湯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/湯) is *soup*, and [包](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/包) is *bun*, so [湯包](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/湯包) is *soup bun*.

These steamed buns, with skin pinched at the top creating vertical ripples all around, are filled with broth and typically pork. They originate from Shanghai so are often known as Shanghai dumplings, or soup dumplings, or Shanghai soup dumplings, or by their Mandarin pronunciation, [xialongbao](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiaolongbao), or the abbreviation XLB.

The skin is usually thin and delicate (although there are variations with thicker dough), so it's a challenge to plop them in your mouth without breaking the skin and spilling the broth (and burning your mouth). The safest and wimpiest method is to place each dumpling in a spoon, then poke the skin and let the broth run out into the spoon.

**Characters**

[小](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%B0%8F) is *small*, [籠](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%B1%A0) is *envelope*, and [包](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8C%85) is *bun*, so  [小籠包](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%B0%8F%E7%B1%A0%E5%8C%85) is *small envelope bun*.

In Shanghainese, they are known as 小籠饅頭 (ending with 饅頭 mantou, the old name for buns, instead of bao).

words.Yale: jyū gū līk síu lùhng bāau
words.Pinyin: qiǎo kè lì xiǎo lóng bāo

description:
One of the more whimsical variations of Shanghai soup dumplings (available at Din Tai Fung and, in Las Vegas, Xialongbao), this is a soup dumpling skin filled with chocolate (in this photo, also with banana). No soup. For dessert.

**Characters**

In Cantonese the [loanword](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanword) for *chocolate* is [朱古力](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%9C%B1%E5%8F%A4%E5%8A%9B), pronounced *jyū gū līk*, and in Mandarin it's [巧克力](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%B7%A7%E5%85%8B%E5%8A%9B), pronounced *qiǎo kè lì*. [小](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/小) is *small*, [籠](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%B1%A0) is *envelope*, and [包](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8C%85) is *bun*, so [小籠包](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%B0%8F%E7%B1%A0%E5%8C%85) is *small envelope bun*.
